articles.headline: Markets Around the World Are Marching in Lock Step
articles.snippet: Major markets around the world now tend to move more in line with one another than ever before, reflecting the dominance of global companies.
articles.abstract: Major markets around the world now tend to move more in line with one another than ever before, reflecting the dominance of global companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five months after stock markets around the world were shaken by a 9 percent plunge in the value of Chinese stocks, the markets have again come under severe pressure — this time made in America.

articles.headline: As U.S. Rebuilds, Iraq Won’t Act on Finished Work
articles.snippet: Iraq’s national government is refusing to take over thousands of reconstruction projects, a report shows.
articles.abstract: Iraq’s national government is refusing to take over thousands of reconstruction projects, a report shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: Iraq’s national government is refusing to take possession of thousands of American-financed reconstruction projects, forcing the United States either to hand them over to local Iraqis, who often lack the proper training and resources to keep the projects running, or commit new money to an effort that has already consumed billions of taxpayer dollars.

articles.headline: The Bigger Ferris Wheels Get, the More Cash Flows
articles.snippet: The success of the London Eye has reinvigorated demand for Ferris wheels around the world, and launched a heated competition to build the world’s tallest.
articles.abstract: The success of the London Eye has reinvigorated demand for Ferris wheels around the world, and launched a heated competition to build the world’s tallest.
articles.lead_paragraph: The London Eye Ferris wheel, inaugurated on Dec. 31, 1999, was only meant to stay a few years. But almost immediately, it was clear that the 443-foot Eye would be a keeper.

articles.headline: Parents’ Ire Grows at Pedophile’s Unabashed Blog
articles.snippet: The Los Angeles police say they have no legal recourse against a man who writes about how he trolls for children.
articles.abstract: The Los Angeles police say they have no legal recourse against a man who writes about how he trolls for children.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, July 27 — The search for the self-described pedophile in the large-brimmed black hat commences nearly every day here, with findings posted on chat rooms frequented by mothers.

articles.headline: Strife and Ice, Staples of Life, Overlap in Iraq
articles.snippet: For Baghdad’s poor, subject to sectarian horrors and gangland rules, ice is a currency of last resort.
articles.abstract: For Baghdad’s poor, subject to sectarian horrors and gangland rules, ice is a currency of last resort.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, July 27 — Each day before the midsummer sun rises high enough to bake blood on concrete, Baghdad’s underclass lines up outside Dickensian ice factories.

articles.headline: On Paying for Cars With Cash
articles.snippet: Much to the chagrin of car dealers, who make a substantial portion of their profits from financing and extras on a sale, the number of people paying cash for new cars is growing.
articles.abstract: Much to the chagrin of car dealers, who make a substantial portion of their profits from financing and extras on a sale, the number of people paying cash for new cars is growing.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, July 27 — There are two questions that greet every car buyer who walks into a showroom: “Are you ready to buy today?” and “How do you plan to pay?”

articles.headline: ‘Harry’ and the Strange Logic of Book Discounters
articles.snippet: With rampant price-cutting, did retailers make much money on the young wizard?
articles.abstract: With rampant price-cutting, did retailers make much money on the young wizard?
articles.lead_paragraph: I had dinner with my daughter, Kate, near Union Square in Manhattan last Friday, and afterward, as we walked toward the subway, we saw a long line snaking around the corner. “Do you know what that is?” she asked. I didn’t. “Harry Potter.”

articles.headline: Wall Street Has Worst Week in Nearly 5 Years
articles.snippet: The Dow was down more than 4 percent for the week, while the Standard & Poor’s 500 fell nearly 5 percent.
articles.abstract: The Dow was down more than 4 percent for the week, while the Standard & Poor’s 500 fell nearly 5 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks fell sharply on Wall Street yesterday, a day after the market tumbled because of worries about slowing domestic growth and tighter borrowing conditions.

articles.headline: Family Shifts Add to Doubt at Dow Jones
articles.snippet: The Bancroft family’s deliberations on a sale of Dow Jones to the News Corporation took several bizarre turns Friday.
articles.abstract: The Bancroft family’s deliberations on a sale of Dow Jones to the News Corporation took several bizarre turns Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The deliberations of the Bancroft family over whether to sell the publisher of The Wall Street Journal to Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation took several bizarre turns yesterday as family members switched sides, sniped at one another and even sought to change the terms of the offer and of their own family trusts.
articles.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: British Pullback in Iraq Presages Hurdles for U.S.
articles.snippet: Skepticism is widespread in Basra, as in Baghdad, about whether Iraqi forces are ready to take over.
articles.abstract: Skepticism is widespread in Basra, as in Baghdad, about whether Iraqi forces are ready to take over.
articles.lead_paragraph: BASRA, Iraq — As American troop levels are peaking in Baghdad, British force levels are heading in the opposite direction as the troops prepare to withdraw completely from the city center of Basra, 300 miles to the south.

articles.headline: Fidelity, Thy Name Is Ned
articles.snippet: Edward C. Johnson III, the 77-year-old chief executive of the FMR Corporation, shows no signs of wanting to alter his managerial style, which endorses constant change.
articles.abstract: Edward C. Johnson III, the 77-year-old chief executive of the FMR Corporation, shows no signs of wanting to alter his managerial style, which endorses constant change.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUMNER Redstone made headlines nine days ago when he made it clear that his only daughter, Shari, would not necessarily succeed him as head of Viacom and CBS, the media conglomerates he controls. But in a little-noticed move, another corporate patriarch also recently distanced himself from his daughter and possible successor.

articles.headline: Summer School for Investors Is in Session
articles.snippet: With the equity markets off sharply for the week and the credit markets seizing, investors are being forced to relearn some of the basics.
articles.abstract: With the equity markets off sharply for the week and the credit markets seizing, investors are being forced to relearn some of the basics.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s still summer but as the financial markets declared last week, back-to-school season for United States investors has arrived.

articles.headline: In the ’60s, a Future Candidate Poured Her Heart Out in Letters
articles.snippet: Letters written by Hillary Rodham provide a rare unfiltered look into the head of a future first lady and would-be president.
articles.abstract: Letters written by Hillary Rodham provide a rare unfiltered look into the head of a future first lady and would-be president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 28 — They were high school friends from Park Ridge, Ill., both high achievers headed East to college. John Peavoy was a bookish film buff bound for Princeton, Hillary Rodham a driven, civic-minded Republican going off to Wellesley. They were not especially close, but they found each other smart and interesting and said they would try to keep in touch.

articles.headline: Decades After a Plant Closes, Waste Remains
articles.snippet: The Ford Motor Company spent years removing sludge from a site near its shuttered plant in Mahwah, N.J. But a lawsuit claims that the automaker has yet to finish the job.
articles.abstract: The Ford Motor Company spent years removing sludge from a site near its shuttered plant in Mahwah, N.J. But a lawsuit claims that the automaker has yet to finish the job.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the summer of 2005, around the time that residents of Upper Ringwood, N.J., began to wonder whether the skin rashes, nose bleeds and bronchitis that plagued their community were more than bad luck, the Ford Motor Company and the Environmental Protection Agency made a request: the automaker and the regulator wanted access to the yards around two families’ homes to remove waste that had been dumped in the area. Ford boasts in its ads that “It’s Easy Being Green,” but residents feared the request suggested something not so easy at all. From the mid-1950s to the late 1970s, Ford operated an assembly plant in northern New Jersey, in nearby Mahwah, that cranked out millions of passenger cars. Ford closed the plant in 1980, after dumping what the E.P.A. describes as thousands of tons of paint sludge and other waste in Upper Ringwood, a community of about 350 working-class residents located in the foothills of the Ramapo Mountains.

articles.headline: Governing Party in Japan Suffers Election Defeat
articles.snippet: The opposition party seized control of the upper house, but Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said he would not step down.
articles.abstract: The opposition party seized control of the upper house, but Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said he would not step down.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Monday, July 30 — Japan’s governing Liberal Democratic Party suffered a crushing defeat Sunday in the election for the upper house of Parliament, but Prime Minister Shinzo Abe vowed that he would not step down.

articles.headline: In Illinois, Obama Proved Pragmatic and Shrewd
articles.snippet: In the Illinois State Senate, Barack Obama brought an eye for opportunity and a willingness to compromise.
articles.abstract: In the Illinois State Senate, Barack Obama brought an eye for opportunity and a willingness to compromise.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was something improbable about the new guy from Chicago via Honolulu and Jakarta, Indonesia, the one with the Harvard law degree and the job teaching constitutional law, turning up in Springfield, Ill., in January 1997 among the housewives, ex-mayors and occasional soybean farmer serving in the State Senate.

articles.headline: New Scrutiny for Facebook Over Predators
articles.snippet: Like MySpace before it, Facebook, the online social network, is being subjected to accusations that it does not do enough to keep sexual predators off its site.
articles.abstract: Like MySpace before it, Facebook, the online social network, is being subjected to accusations that it does not do enough to keep sexual predators off its site.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 — Facebook, the online social network, has stolen some of MySpace’s momentum with users and the news media. Now, it is being subjected to the same accusations that it does not do enough to keep sexual predators off its site.

articles.headline: Monday on Wall St.: Jitters Rather Than Mergers
articles.snippet: Given the rout in the financial markets last week, “Merger Monday” may be suspended — indefinitely.
articles.abstract: Given the rout in the financial markets last week, “Merger Monday” may be suspended — indefinitely.
articles.lead_paragraph: Monday, the day when Wall Street announces some of its biggest deals, may not be the same for a while. And that could cause more jitters in stock and bond markets, following their worst week in nearly five years.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Eric Dash

articles.headline: In Baghdad, Justice Behind the Barricades
articles.snippet: The Americans and the Iraqi government have erected a legal Green Zone to shelter judges and secure the trials of some of Iraq’s most dangerous suspects.
articles.abstract: The Americans and the Iraqi government have erected a legal Green Zone to shelter judges and secure the trials of some of Iraq’s most dangerous suspects.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, July 26 — In a city plagued by suicide bombers and renegade militias, the Americans and the Iraqi government have turned to an unusual measure to help implant the rule of law: they have erected a legal Green Zone, a heavily fortified compound to shelter judges and their families and secure the trials of some of the most dangerous suspects.

articles.headline: Microsoft’s Gates Plans Leave Amid Great Change
articles.snippet: Bill Gates, who co-founded Microsoft, still intends to step away next year as planned. But so far, Mr. Gates, the company’s chairman, is showing no sign of fading away.
articles.abstract: Bill Gates, who co-founded Microsoft, still intends to step away next year as planned. But so far, Mr. Gates, the company’s chairman, is showing no sign of fading away.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash., July 27 — Microsoft is beset with competition from all sides, unlike any it has seen in decades, and Bill Gates, who co-founded the company 32 years ago, still intends to step away next year as planned.

articles.headline: The Ludlum Conundrum: A Dead Novelist Provides New Thrills
articles.snippet: Robert Ludlum died six years ago, but that has done nothing to slow the release of books published under the name of the actor-turned-novelist.
articles.abstract: Robert Ludlum died six years ago, but that has done nothing to slow the release of books published under the name of the actor-turned-novelist.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert Ludlum died six years ago, but that has done nothing to slow the release of books published under the name of the actor-turned-novelist who specialized in thrillers built on a foundation of paranoia.

articles.headline: China-U.S. Talks Continue, Amid Legal Volleys
articles.snippet: A year after the United States began a “strategic economic dialogue” with China, the word “dialogue” hardly seems to apply.
articles.abstract: A year after the United States began a “strategic economic dialogue” with China, the word “dialogue” hardly seems to apply.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 28 — A year after the United States began a high-level “strategic economic dialogue” with China, the word “dialogue” hardly seems to apply.

articles.headline: Without U.S. Rules, Biotech Food Lacks Investors
articles.snippet: As U.S. officials get serious about drafting rules for the industry, some scientists and executives say big investors may finally be willing to put up money.
articles.abstract: As U.S. officials get serious about drafting rules for the industry, some scientists and executives say big investors may finally be willing to put up money.
articles.lead_paragraph: This little piggy’s manure causes less pollution. This little piggy produces extra milk for her babies. And this little piggy makes fatty acids normally found in fish, so that eating its bacon might actually be good for you.
